skills.name: Answer decimal problems that require the use of multiplication and division
Calculate the whole amount, given a fraction of the amount
Use direct proportion to solve non-unitary missing amounts in problems (e.g. recipes)
Recognise units that speed can be measured in
Calculate distance where speed and time are in units that need to be changed

explanations.A: I think you have found 100% of the value, can you find 20%?
explanations.B: It looks like you've added on 5, rather than 5%. To answer this, try to find out what 5% is worth first.
explanations.C: It looks like you've found 20% of 120, whereas 15% is 120, it might help to find 5% first.
explanations.D: If 15% is 120, then we can find 5% by calculating 120/3 = 40, and then 20% is 40 × 4 = 160.

explanations.A: If 15% is 75, then we can find 5% by calculating 75/3 = 25, and then 20% is 25 × 4 = 100.
explanations.B: I think you have found 100% of the value, can you find 20%?

explanations.D: You have found what 5% of the value would be, instead we want to find what 20% of the original value would be. How can use your 5% to get to 20%?

explanations.A: If 2/3 of the whole song is 150 seconds, then 1/3 of the whole song is half of this (150/2 = 75). The whole song is equal to 3 x 1/3 of the song = 3 x 75 = 225.
explanations.B: Close! This is the length of 1-third of the song. How can we use this to find the length of the whole song?
explanations.C: Not quite! 150 seconds is the length of 2-thirds of the song not 1-half. How can we find the length of 1-third of the song? How could we use this to find the length of the whole song?
explanations.D: Not quite! I think you have found 2/3 of 150 BUT we are told 150 is the length of 2-thirds of the song. How can we find the length of 1-third of the song? How could we use this to find the length of the whole song?

explanations.A: Not quite! You have multiplied by 3 here. If 60 seconds is 3-quarters, try working out what 1-quarter of the song would be in seconds and from there multiplying to get 4-quarters (or one whole).
explanations.B: Close! This is the length of 1-quarter of the song. How can we use this to find the length of the whole song?
explanations.C: Not quite! You have multiplied by 4 here. If 60 seconds is 3-quarters, try working out what 1-quarter of the song would be in seconds and from there multiplying to get 4-quarters (or one whole).
explanations.D: If 60 seconds is 3/4 then we need to divide by 3 to work out how many seconds 1/4 of the song is. 60 divided by 3 = 20. Four quarters is therefore 20 x 4 = 80 seconds in total. You could also do the calculation in one step by multiplying 60 by 4/3 to get 80 seconds.

explanations.A: This is the area of the whole circle. How much is just the white section?
explanations.B: 1 section has an area of 0.9/3 = 0.3m², and so the 5 white sections have an area of 0.3 × 5 = 1.5m².
explanations.C: Almost, this is the area of one section. How many sections do we have for the white part?
explanations.D: Not quite. Remember the 0.9 is all 3 blue sections. Work out one section first, and then you can find the white sections.

explanations.A: There are 5 white sections so we divide the total area by 5 to get an area of 0.3m² for each white section. There are 3 blue sections, so we multiply 0.3 by 3 to get 0.9m².
explanations.B: This is the area of the whole circle. How much is just the blue section?
explanations.C: Almost, this is the area of one section. How many sections do we have for the blue part?
explanations.D: Not quite. Remember the 1.5 is all 5 white sections. Work out one section first, and then you can find the blue sections.

explanations.A: Multiplying 30 by 40 tells us how far the tuk tuk travels in 40 hours but we need the distance in 40 minutes. What fraction of an hour is 40 minutes? How far will the tuk tuk travel if they travel for this fraction of an hour?
explanations.B: We can find out 40 minutes as a fraction of an hour by calculating 40/60= 2/3 hours. We can then use distance = speed x time: so we have 30 × 2/3 = 20 miles.
explanations.C: We need to work out what fraction of an hour 40 minutes is. Remember there are 60 minutes in an hour, and then use this to calculate the distance using the speed.
explanations.D: It looks like you have divided speed by time, but we need to use distance = speed x time to answer this question.

explanations.A: Not quite. Multiplying 30 by 40 tells us how far the tuk tuk travels in 30 hours, but we need 30 minutes. What fraction of an hour is 30 minutes? How far will the tuk tuk travel if they travel for this fraction of an hour?
explanations.B: We need to work out what 30 minutes is as a fraction of an hour. Remember there are 60 minutes in an hour. Then you can use this to calculate the distance using the speed.
explanations.C: We can find out 30 minutes as a fraction of an hour by calculating 30/60= 1/2 hour = t. Speed = 40mph. So we can use the formula D = sxt = 40 x 1/2 to get 20 miles.
explanations.D: It looks like you have divided speed by time, but we need to use distance = speed x time to answer this question.

explanations.A: We know that speed = distance / time, which of these options shows a unit of distance divided by a unit of time?
explanations.B: Kilometre is a measurement of distance and hour is a measurement of time, so we have distance/time = speed.
explanations.C: We know that speed = distance / time, which of these options shows a unit of distance divided by a unit of time?
explanations.D: We know that speed = distance / time, which of these options shows a unit of distance divided by a unit of time?

explanations.A: Speed is measured distance / time, what option shows a unit of distance divided by a unit of time?
explanations.B: You have chosen a unit of time divided by a unit of distance. Remember that speed = distance / time.
explanations.C: You have chosen a unit of time divided by a unit of distance. Remember that speed = distance / time.
explanations.D: Speed is measured by Distance/Time, kilometres are a unit of distance and seconds are a unit of time, so km/second is the correct answer.
